items.title: Did AI companies win a fight with authors? Technically
items.author: Adi Robertson

items.title: Lamborghini Revuelto review: perfect harmony
items.author: Peter Nelson
items.summary: - The 2025 Lamborghini Revuelto is the brand's first plug-in hybrid supercar, combining a 6.5L V12 engine with three electric motors for a total of 1,001 hp and impressive dynamics. - It delivers exceptional performance with 0-60 mph in 2.5 seconds, immersive V12 sound, and enhanced cornering thanks to advanced aerodynamics, a lightweight chassis, and adaptive suspension. - Despite its power, it offers respectable fuel economy (23 MPGe), making it a thrilling yet somewhat efficient hypercar that redefines hybrid high-performance vehicles.

items.title: Facebook is starting to feed its AI with private, unpublished photos
items.author: Tina Nguyen
items.summary:
- Meta is expanding its AI training data to include billions of unpublished photos from users' camera rolls through an opt-in 'cloud processing' feature.  
- This feature allows Meta's AI to analyze private photos, facial features, and other metadata, raising privacy concerns since it's unclear if these images are excluded from AI training.  
- Users can opt out to remove photos after 30 days, but Meta is already offering AI-enhanced suggestions on past photos without explicit user consent, signaling a deeper invasion of privacy beyond posted content.

items.title: US Critical Infrastructure Cyber Vulnerability
items.author: Justine Calma
items.summary: - US critical infrastructure like water, healthcare, and energy are highly vulnerable to cyberattacks due to increased connectivity yet insufficient cybersecurity resources. - State-sponsored groups such as China's Volt Typhoon have compromised water facilities, highlighting the risks amid geopolitical tensions, especially concerning Taiwan and Iran. - Experts advocate for affordable, practical engineering solutions alongside cybersecurity to mitigate damage, emphasizing expanded public-private partnerships and volunteer cyber resilience efforts at state and local levels.

items.title: Logitech says all its webcams work with Nintendo Switch 2, save one
items.author: Sean Hollister
items.summary:
- *Logitech confirms* that all its webcams except the high-end Brio 4K work *out of the box* with the Nintendo Switch 2's new GameChat feature.  
- Manufacturers faced a *mystery* as many webcams initially failed to connect with the Switch 2 due to lack of official guidelines, forcing them to *reverse-engineer* compatibility and update firmware.  
- Other brands like Elgato and Ugreen are also updating webcams for compatibility, while some users report unofficial Brio 4K support via firmware downgrades, albeit at *risk*.

items.title: The Nothing Phone 3 might have the weirdest camera design out there
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary:
- The *Nothing Phone 3* is rumored to feature a translucent back with a uniquely *weird camera layout*, including two cameras side by side and one isolated in a phone corner.
- This design contrasts typical smartphone cameras that are neatly aligned in triangles or bars, presenting potentially the boldest layout yet, reminiscent but bolder than the Nothing 3A Pro.
- Official teases, including a 50MP periscope lens image and a "Glyph Matrix" feature, suggest these designs are authentic; the phone will be revealed on July 1st alongside new headphones.

items.title: Best Gaming Laptops Tested by The Verge
items.author: Antonio G. Di Benedetto
items.summary: - The Asus ROG Zephyrus G14 remains the top pick for a balanced *gaming laptop* combining portability, OLED display, and solid performance, albeit with some heat and noise under load. - The MSI Titan 18 HX, though *astronomically expensive*, offers unmatched power with an 18-inch 4K Mini LED display, top-tier CPU and GPU options, making it the *most powerful* gaming laptop available. - Mid-to-high-tier laptops like the Asus ROG Strix Scar 16 and Lenovo Legion Pro 7i provide excellent gaming performance, lots of ports, and strong displays with RTX 5080 GPUs at more accessible prices, but share typical gaming laptop compromises like weight and battery life.

items.title: Runway to Enable AI-Generated Video Games
items.author: Alex Heath
items.summary:
- Runway, known for AI in Hollywood, is expanding into the gaming industry with plans to release AI-generated video games later this year.  
- The company is developing a chat interface for text and image generation with gaming capabilities coming, and is in talks with gaming companies to use their tech and data.  
- CEO Cristóbal Valenzuela compares the gaming AI adoption to Hollywood's experience and values the company's independence despite acquisition interest from Meta.

items.title: Trump's 'big beautiful bill' could slow down 6GHz Wi-Fi
items.author: Jennifer Pattison Tuohy
items.summary:
- The Senate’s budget bill, supported by Donald Trump, proposes auctioning 800 MHz of the 6GHz unlicensed spectrum to mobile carriers, potentially *slowing Wi-Fi speeds* by reducing available bandwidth for Wi-Fi 6E and Wi-Fi 7 devices.
- This spectrum reallocation could generate government revenue but faces criticism from tech companies like Apple, Amazon, and Meta, who warn it threatens *future tech growth* in AI, AR/VR, and smart home innovations.
- While proponents argue that auctioning the spectrum prepares carriers for the next wireless leap, some carriers like AT&T currently see *no urgent need* for more spectrum, raising questions about the bill’s impact on consumers.

items.title: Eufy’s Omni C20 mopping robovac is $300 off for a limited time
items.author: Brandon Russell
items.summary:
- The **Eufy Omni C20** is a robot vacuum and mop combo with automated features like emptying, washing, drying, and refilling the mop, currently discounted by $300 to $399.98 for a limited time.
- It has dual sweeping and mopping modules with 180 rotations per minute, 7,000Pa suction, and a pro-detangle comb to handle dirt, tough stains, and pet hair, but lacks obstacle avoidance.
- Other notable deals include the Super Mario Odyssey digital game, BioLite Solar Site Lights, and Apple Watch Series 10 at discounted prices.

items.title: Google's carbon emissions just went up again
items.author: Emma Roth
items.summary:
- Google's carbon emissions increased by **11 percent** last year, reaching 11.5 million metric tons, a **51 percent increase since 2019**, due to AI expansion.  
- The company's total emissions, including supply chain and peripheral activities, are around **15.2 million metric tons**, equivalent to nearly 40 gas-fired power plants.  
- External challenges like AI's unpredictable energy needs, policy changes, and slow carbon-free energy rollout complicate Google's climate goals despite data center emission reductions.

items.title: Where to Buy microSD Express Cards for Nintendo Switch 2
items.author: Cameron Faulkner
items.summary:
- The Nintendo Switch 2 requires *microSD Express* cards for storing and playing games, offering a 4.4x faster data transfer than previous microSD cards compatible with the original Switch.  
- These microSD Express cards are notably *more expensive*, with typical prices over $50 for 256GB, and up to $200 for 1TB, although Walmart's Onn brand provides some more affordable options.  
- The new Switch 2 includes 256GB of built-in storage, potentially reducing the urgency for an upgrade, and multiple brands like Samsung, PNY, Onn, Sandisk, GameStop, and Lexar offer compatible cards currently available online.

items.title: The best deals on 4K TVs
items.author: Brandt Ranj
items.summary:
- The article highlights great *2025 discounts* on various 4K TVs including models from Samsung, TCL, Panasonic, Amazon, Hisense, and LG, tailored for different budgets and needs.
- It features *highlights* like Samsung Q8F's 120Hz QLED panel, TCL QM7K's bright QD-Mini LED, Panasonic Z85's budget OLED, and LG G5 OLED for premium gaming and cinematic experience.
- Budget options include Amazon Fire TV 4-Series and Hisense QD7, both offering solid performance for their price, with features like HDR support and AI upscaling.

items.title: Riot Games Embraces Sports Betting Sponsorships for Esports Leagues
items.author: Ash Parrish
items.summary:
- Riot Games has opened its *League of Legends* and *Valorant* esports leagues in the Americas and Europe to sports betting sponsorships, aiming to generate new revenue amid the 'esports winter' downturn.  
- The move allows tier one esports organizations to secure paid sponsorships from gambling companies under strict guidelines to ensure responsibility and integrity.  
- This decision carries risks around *competitive integrity* and exposure of young audiences to gambling promotion, amid existing match-fixing concerns and prior esports controversies.

items.title: Adobe's Project Indigo: A Camera App for Camera Nerds
items.author: Allison Johnson
items.summary:
- Adobe’s Project Indigo is a camera app designed for photography enthusiasts, emphasizing *natural-looking multi-frame computational processing* and offering detailed control over capture and image processing.  
- Indigo produces less aggressively sharpened photos with warmer tones and better preservation of shadows and highlights, providing a more *thoughtfully designed HDR experience* than standard phone cameras.  
- While it demands *more processing power, causes heating, and drains battery*, it offers computational RAW capture on some iPhones and invites users into the normally opaque photo-taking process, appealing especially to camera nerds.

items.title: Tesla Executive Changes Amid Challenges
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary: - Tesla experienced key executive departures including the firing of Omead Afshar, who led North American and European operations, after a sales slump and internal investigations. - VP Milan Kovac left Tesla’s Optimus humanoid robotics team to spend more time with family, highlighting further executive turnover. - Tesla hired Henry Kuang from GM Cruise as Director of AI/Deep Learning to boost its autonomous robotaxi efforts despite a rocky initial launch.

items.title: Google quietly introduced precise Bluetooth tracking on the Pixel Watch 3
items.author: Andrew Liszewski
items.summary: - Google released Wear OS 5.1 update enabling *Channel Sounding* on Pixel Watch 3, improving Bluetooth location tracking accuracy. - Channel Sounding measures signal timing over multiple frequencies, offering *centimeter-level accuracy and directional awareness* without extra hardware. - Adoption depends on more devices and software supporting Bluetooth 6.0, promising advanced tracking akin to Ultra-Wideband but without increased hardware costs.

items.title: Supreme Court Upholds Texas Porn Age-Gating Law
items.author: Adi Robertson
items.summary:
- The Supreme Court ruled 6-3 in *Free Speech Coalition v. Paxton* to uphold Texas law HB 1181, requiring *age verification* for adult websites, stating it only *incidentally burdens adult speech*.
- The ruling marks a shift from earlier decisions due to *technological advances* making content more accessible to minors and allows states more power to restrict obscene material for children.
- Dissenting justices and free speech advocates warn of *privacy concerns* and *chilling effects* on adults’ rights; similar laws are emerging for social media verification.

items.title: Supreme Court Upheld Low-Income Broadband Subsidy Fund
items.author: Lauren Feiner
items.summary: - The Supreme Court ruled the *Universal Service Fund* (USF), a key broadband subsidy for schools and underserved communities, can continue operating, rejecting claims it was unconstitutional. - The USF subsidizes telecom services for *low-income consumers*, rural health providers, schools, and libraries, administered by a nonprofit designated by the FCC. - Justice Kagan affirmed Congress sufficiently constrained the FCC's role, preserving governmental accountability, which the Court said does *not* violate the Constitution.

items.title: FTC Reopens Fortnite Settlement Refund Claims
items.author: Jess Weatherbed
items.summary: - The *FTC has reopened* refund claims for Fortnite players misled into unwanted purchases, extending the deadline to July 9th. - Nearly **$200 million** in refunds have been sent to eligible U.S. players since December 2024. - Claims apply to players charged from 2017 to 2022, including unauthorized child charges and account locks after disputes.

items.title: Google’s Doppl app took off my socks
items.author: Emma Roth

items.title: Gentex's Place Smart Smoke Alarm: A Potential Nest Protect Replacement
items.author: Jennifer Pattison Tuohy
items.summary:
- Gentex has launched Place, a new line of smart smoke and CO alarms with features like phone notifications, nightlight, motion detection, and optional air quality monitoring and camera.
- Starting at $139, models include base, kitchen, nursery, and garage alarms with varying features such as VOC detection, white noise, and intercom.
- While currently only Alexa-compatible, Gentex aims for Matter integration to enable broad smart home compatibility, addressing a gap left by discontinued Nest Protect.

items.title: M3gan 2.0 is a fun upgrade that’s a little too self-aware
items.author: Charles Pulliam-Moore
items.summary: - *M3gan 2.0* builds on the original's campy AI doll premise with bigger budget sci-fi action, blending horror and thriller elements. - The sequel introduces a new, more violent AI robot but struggles with heavy-handed themes and less compelling human characters. - Despite solid scares and fun action, the movie's *self-awareness* and focus on philosophical ideas dilute its thrilling essence.

items.title: What Meta and Anthropic really won in court
items.author: David Pierce
items.summary:
- The article discusses recent *court rulings* where Meta and Anthropic won *fair use* cases related to AI training data and copyright.
- It highlights the ongoing *copyright battles* between creative industries and AI companies over data use and generated outputs.
- The verdicts are seen as a *partial victory*, with judges signaling the need for clearer laws and better arguments in future cases.

items.title: Threads Improves Word Filtering with Custom and Temporary Options
items.author: Jess Weatherbed
items.summary: - *Threads now offers its own Hidden Words filter* separate from Instagram, allowing users to block words, phrases, and emojis in batches with *optional time limits.* - The update supports *temporary snoozing* of words (up to 30 days), useful for avoiding spoilers or drama. - This feature enhances user control and comfort in shaping their social media experience.

items.title: Graphic artists in China push back on AI and its averaging effect
items.author: Gus Rick
items.summary: - *Chinese graphic artists* face challenges as AI image generators alter the creative process and client expectations. - AI enables quick style copying but often produces low-quality or unoriginal results, useful more as *a toy than a tool*. - Designers stress that their work involves *creative strategy* beyond image production, now undervalued by clients expecting faster, cheaper outputs.

items.title: Redwood Materials Repurposes Old EV Batteries into Cost-Effective Microgrids
items.author: Andrew J. Hawkins
items.summary:
- *Redwood Materials* repurposes old EV batteries into *low-cost, large-scale energy storage systems* instead of recycling them immediately.
- The company manages over 20 GWh of batteries annually, with many still retaining up to *50% usable capacity*.
- Its first microgrid in Nevada powers a 2,000-GPU data center, demonstrating a sustainable *second-life battery deployment* with significant energy capacity.

items.title: Meta Claims Victory in Talent War with OpenAI; AI Trends & Legal Battles
items.author: Alex Heath
items.summary: - **Meta's CTO Andrew Bosworth** disputes OpenAI CEO Sam Altman's claim of $100M signing bonuses, highlighting selective hiring of *top senior AI talent*. - Meta aims to *differentiate its AI* by focusing on entertainment and social connection, unlike OpenAI's productivity focus. - Legal clash heats up as Iyo sues OpenAI over trademark 'io' linked to upcoming AI devices, with rivalry extending into the AI hardware space. - Runway, a $3B generative AI startup, expands into *gaming AI*, paralleling Hollywood’s gradual AI adoption. - Several key OpenAI researchers have joined Meta, fueling the ongoing *competition for AI talent* in the industry.

items.title: Google Rolls Out AI-Powered 'Ask Photos' Search with Speed Boost
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary: - Google is expanding access to its AI-powered 'Ask Photos' search in Google Photos, powered by its Gemini AI models. - The update addresses earlier concerns about *latency, quality,* and *user experience* by delivering faster results for simple queries while continuing to refine results in the background. - The feature is now rolling out to more *eligible US users* beyond early access.

items.title: Apple Revamps EU App Store Rules After €500M Penalty
items.author: Emma Roth
items.summary: - Apple introduces a *new tier system* for its EU App Store fees, limiting some features to developers paying a higher commission. - A *5% Core Technology Commission* is added on external app purchases, transitioning from an annual €0.50 download fee by 2026. - Changes respond to a *€500 million EU penalty* for anti-steering practices violating Digital Markets Act, which Apple plans to appeal.

items.title: Ember’s Temperature-Controlled Smart Mug Now $89.99
items.author: Sheena Vasani
items.summary: - The **Ember Mug 2** keeps drinks hot with a self-heating feature and app-controlled temperature from *125°F to 145°F*. - Available on Amazon, Best Buy, and Walmart for an all-time low of **$89.99** (saving $60). - Features include up to 80 mins battery life, scratch-resistant coating, IPX7 water resistance, and customizable LED light.

items.title: Microsoft’s Xbox PC launcher integrates Steam, Epic, and more
items.author: Tom Warren
items.summary: - Microsoft is testing a new consolidated PC gaming library in the Xbox app that lists games from *Steam, Epic, Battle.net, Ubisoft,* and *Riot Games* installed on a PC. - The integration automatically detects games, displays them with thumbnails and launcher info, and allows hiding unwanted games. - While it offers no new gameplay features, this is part of enhancing the Xbox app as *the home of PC gaming* on Windows and improving handheld device experiences.

items.title: The Xbox 360 dashboard just got updated… to advertise newer Xboxes
items.author: Andrew Liszewski

items.title: Comcast Simplifies Xfinity Plans and Removes Data Caps
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary:
- Comcast is simplifying its Xfinity internet plans nationwide to four tiers: 300 Mbps, 500 Mbps, 1 Gbps, and 2 Gbps.
- All plans now offer *truly unlimited data* with no data caps, including an Xfinity WiFi Gateway and one year of free Xfinity Mobile service.
- Customers can choose from pricing with no guarantee, one-year, or five-year price guarantees, increasing plan flexibility and value.

items.title: Gemini set to replace Google Assistant on Android with improved privacy
items.author: Jess Weatherbed
items.summary: - *Gemini* will soon control Android device features like messaging and calls even when *Apps Activity* is off, enhancing *user privacy*. - This update allows users to disable AI training use of their chat data while still enjoying assistant functionalities. - *Gemini* will replace Google Assistant on Android later this year, offering better privacy controls and convenience.

items.title: The Delta Emulator Creator Launches Game Boy Camera-Style iPhone App
items.author: Andrew Liszewski
items.summary:
- Riley Testut, creator of the Delta emulator, released the Delta Camera app replicating the classic Game Boy Camera's 128x128 monochrome photos with *modern features*.
- The app includes manual exposure, zoom, multi-shot panoramas, and full iPhone Camera Control support.
- Currently in beta via Patreon, it offers a *nostalgic yet social media-friendly* way to capture retro-style images on iPhone.

items.title: Hisense’s latest smart air conditioner is on sale for just $249.99
items.author: Brandt Ranj
items.summary:
- *Hisense’s BTUWC08W25A smart air conditioner* cools rooms up to 350 sq ft with 8,000 BTU and four-directional airflow.
- It's *controllable via remote, touch buttons, or a mobile app* for convenience, priced at a record low $249.99 on Amazon.
- The article also highlights deals on a *Sony waterproof Bluetooth speaker* and a *Samsung 4K monitor*.

items.title: The pharma CEOs aren’t safe in new trailer for Yorgos Lanthimos’ Bugonia
items.author: Charles Pulliam-Moore
items.summary: - *Bugonia*, directed by Yorgos Lanthimos, is a remake of the 2003 South Korean film *Save the Green Planet*. - The story follows Teddy, a beekeeper and pharma worker, who believes CEO Michelle is alien, sparking a kidnapping plot. - The film explores *economic inequality* and *mental health* struggles, premiering October 24 with a wide release on October 31.

items.title: YouTube launches AI-powered search results carousel
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary:
- **YouTube introduces an AI-powered search results carousel** for Premium members in the US focused on shopping, travel, and local activities.
- The feature displays a large top video, thumbnails of relevant clips, and an AI-generated text summary, currently on iOS and Android.
- Access is limited to randomly selected Premium users until July 30th; conversational AI features also expand to some non-Premium US users.

items.title: Google’s Gemini AI Fills Empty Cells in Sheets
items.author: Emma Roth
items.summary: - **Google Gemini AI** introduces a new Sheets function to generate text that fills spreadsheet cells, such as ad copy or customer feedback summaries. - The AI can reference specific cells but is limited to text-only responses and 200 cells at a time. - This feature is rolling out to select **Google Workspace**, Gemini AI Pro/Ultra, and Education plan users.

items.title: Microsoft moves antivirus providers out of the Windows kernel
items.author: Tom Warren
items.summary: - Microsoft is developing a new Windows endpoint security platform to move antivirus (AV) and EDR apps out of the Windows kernel, reducing the risk of system crashes like last year’s CrowdStrike update issue. - The initiative involves collaboration with major vendors like CrowdStrike, Bitdefender, and Trend Micro, focusing on building a secure and reliable API together. - A private preview for security vendors will launch soon, with plans to also address kernel-level anti-cheating drivers in games in the future.

items.title: What is an Xbox?
items.author: Tom Warren
items.summary: - Microsoft is redefining Xbox from just a gaming console to a multi-device platform *across phones, PCs, TVs, and VR*. - The new Xbox Ally handhelds stream games rather than natively run Xbox titles, signaling a shift towards an *Xbox-as-a-service* model similar to Steam. - AMD partnership highlights a *next-gen Xbox ecosystem* with custom chips for consoles, handhelds, PCs, and cloud gaming, aiming for Windows to become the *top gaming platform*.

items.title: Windows is getting rid of the Blue Screen of Death after 40 years
items.author: Tom Warren

items.title: Insta360 Flow 2 Gimbal: Affordable but Missing Pro Features
items.author: Andrew Liszewski
items.summary:
- The *Insta360 Flow 2* is a new, more affordable smartphone gimbal priced at **$110**, offering features from the Pro model like multi-person tracking and Apple Watch remote control.
- It *sacrifices pro capabilities* such as compatibility with alternate camera apps (including iPhone’s native app), missing a selfie mirror, ring light, and infinite 360-degree panning.
- The gimbal uses *Insta360’s Deep Track 4.0* via its app for tracking, with an optional $20 accessory to enable preferred camera app use.

items.title: The BBC is launching a paywall in the US
items.author: Emma Roth
items.summary:
- The BBC will introduce an **$8.99/month subscription** in the US for unlimited access to news, feature reports, and the BBC News livestream.
- Free access remains for select breaking news, radio livestreams, newsletters, and podcasts, using a **dynamic pay model** to balance casual and engaged readers.
- This move aims to increase revenue amid declining UK license fees and will initially only apply to North America, leaving UK access unchanged.

items.title: Denis Villeneuve to Direct Next James Bond Film for Amazon
items.author: Charles Pulliam-Moore
items.summary: - *Denis Villeneuve* has been announced as the director for the next *James Bond* film, Amazon MGM's first Bond project after acquiring the franchise.  - The new film currently lacks a title, cast, or production timeline, with Villeneuve describing the role as a "massive responsibility". - Amazon MGM aims for a theatrical release, betting on Villeneuve's acclaimed visual and storytelling style to refresh the iconic spy series.

items.title: Intel is closing its automotive chipmaking business
items.author: Emma Roth
items.summary: - **Intel is shutting down its automotive chip division**, laying off most employees to focus on core client and data center products. - Despite investing heavily and powering over 50 million vehicles, Intel is winding down this business amid a corporate restructuring. - New CEO Lip-Bu Tan is reducing workforce size, including layoffs in foundry and automotive sectors.

items.title: Bose SoundLink Plus review: here’s your new beach speaker
items.author: John.Higgins
items.summary:
- The Bose SoundLink Plus is a *durable* and *attractively designed* portable Bluetooth speaker with an IP67 rating for water resistance, ideal for beach or pool use.
- It delivers *impressive, loud sound* with good bass but shows some distortion at high volumes and lacks wired audio, Wi-Fi, or AirPlay.
- Priced at $269, it sits between cheaper competitors and pricier full-feature options, making it a good pick for Bose fans but less compelling overall.

items.title: Dell’s new Premium laptops replace XPS with minimal changes
items.author: Jess Weatherbed
items.summary: - Dell has replaced its XPS line with new Premium 14 and 16 laptops, featuring Intel Core Ultra Series 2 processors and a refreshed logo. - The Dell 16 Premium offers Nvidia RTX 5060 at launch, with RTX 5050, 5070, and Intel Arc variants coming soon, plus Thunderbolt 5 on RTX 5070. - The Dell 14 Premium maxes out at 64GB RAM and offers Wi-Fi 7, but overall design and features closely mirror last year's XPS models.

items.title: AI is ruining houseplant communities online
items.author: Nicole Froio
items.summary: - AI-generated images of fake, often impossibly colorful plants are misleading consumers and spreading misinformation in plant communities online. - Experts warn that fake AI content disrupts real community engagement and devalues genuine plant care knowledge. - The rise of AI scams and misinformation may erode the wonder and mindfulness that come with real plant growing.
